questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents with a fever and headache. She also complains of vaginal itching and dysuria. When asked, she says that she recently became sexually active. Physical examination reveals tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and red, pustular, painful vesicles on her labia majora. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HSV

  • Typical vesicles or pustules or a cluster of painful ulcers preceded by vesiculopustular lesions suggestsgenital herpes.
  • The pathognomonic findings for herpes infections are painful vesicles.
  • Both HSV-1 and HSV-2 can cause genital herpes, but more than 80% of genital lesions are due to HSV-2.
  • HSV-2 is transmitted by direct contact of the virus with mucosal surfaces or open skin surfaces.
  • Approximately 80% of infected patients are asymptomatic.

C/F

  • The primary infection presents with constitutional symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia.
  • Later, genital vesicles may appear that can rupture and leave behindpainfululcers.
  • Other genital symptoms include itching andtender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
CHARACTERISTIC SYPHILIS HERPES CHANCROID LGV DONOVANOSIS
Primary lesion Papule Vesicle Pustule Papule, vesicle pustule Papule
Number of lesions Usually 1 Multiple Multiple Single Variable
Diameter 5-15 mm 1-2 mm Variable 2-10 mm Variable
Edges Sharply demarcated elevated Erythematous Polycyclic Undermined Ragged Elevated Round or oval Elevated Irregular
Depth Superficial or deep Superficial Excavated Superficial Or deep Elevated
Base Smooth Non-purulent Covered with serous exudate Erythematous Purulent Dirty grey Base Variable Red Velvety Bleeds easily
Induration Buttonhole None not indurated not indurated not indurated
Lymphadenopathy Shotty lymph nodes Palpable tender Large inflamed bubo Bubos - inflammatory No lymphadenopathy.
Pain Painless Painful Painful Bubos - tender Painless

questions.text: A patient came in with erythematous plaques with silvery-white scaling. On rubbing and removing these scales we see pinpoint bleeding spots. Which of the following medication cannot be used topically for this patient?
questions.solution:
Psoriasis lesions are surmounted by silvery-white scales, which vary considerably in thickness.

When scaling is not evident it can often be induced by light scratching from the blunt edge of the slide - Gentle scratching and rubbing alter the visibility of scaling. (Grattage test)

Scratching scale in psoriasis makes the scale appear more silvery in color by introducing air-keratin interfaces.

On grattage, characteristic coherence of the scales can be seen as if one scratches a wax candle -signe de la tache de bougie.

The successive removal of scales usually reveals an underlying smooth, glossy red membrane (membrane of Berkeley) with small bleeding points where the thin suprapapillary epidermis has been torn off -Auspitz’s Sign.

Treatment

  • Topical
    • Corticosteroids (systemic corticosteroids are C/I)
    • Keratolytic agents (helps remove scaling)
      • Salicylic acid
      • Coal tar
  • Vitamin D analogs
    • Calcitriol
    • Calcipotriol
  • Dithranol (Anthralins)

Systemic

  • Methotrexate

S/e: Hepatotoxic, Teratogenic

  • Acitretin (systemic retinoid)

S/e: teratogenic, dyslipidemia

  • Cyclosporine

S/e: Nephrotoxic, Renal HTN, Hypertriglyceridemia, Hypertrichosis

PhototherapyPUVA, Sol. NBUVB (311nm), Targeted phototherapy (308nm)

  • Internal Organs → Congested
  • Stomach →Wischnewski Spots (Multiple Mucosal Haemorrhages)

questions.text: A primigravida mother gives birth to a newborn. Safety precautions were followed properly and the umbilical cord was clamped. When can we expect the inflammatory ring around the umbilical cord after birth?

  • M → 2 days - Inflammatory ring around the cord
  • Falls → 3 day - Mummified cord
  • 5 day - Cord falls
  • 10 day - Cord heals with a scar

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with headache, pallor, and fever for the past two days. The patient addressed that despite taking tablets for fever, the temperature did not decrease to normal. Upon examination, swelling over the mastoid surface was noted. The doctor used an ophthalmoscope and checked for bulging of retinal veins while simultaneously pressing the Internal jugular vein of the ipsilateral side. What is this method known as?
questions.solution:
Sigmoid / Lateral Sinus Thrombosis

C/F

  • Pallor
  • Headache
  • Picket Fence Fever
  • Temperature does not come to the normal baseline
  • Remittent fever [Intermittent fever seen in malaria]

Management

1) Tobey Ayer / Queckenstedt test

  • Compression over IJV on the normal side, increases CSF pressure in lateral sinus thrombosis
  • Invasive test

2) Crow beck test

  • Compression over IJV on the same side leads to engorgement of Retinal veins.

3) CECT / MRI

  • Empty Delta sign
  • Confirmatory

  • Rx → Surgery + IV Antibiotics

questions.text: A 20-month-old male infant was brought by his mother for fall injury with abrasions on both knees. During the examination, the doctor inspected several injuries in different areas of the body and had disparency between history and physical examination findings. A differential diagnosis of Caffey syndrome was made. What is the most consistent component of the triad of injuries in this condition?
questions.solution:
BATTERED BABY SYNDROME

  • AKA CAFFEY SYNDROME
  • AKA KEMPE SYNDROME
  • AKA INFANT TRAUMATIC STRESS SYNDROME
  • BATTERED CHILD
    • One who received repetitive physical injuries
    • As a result of non-accidental violence
    • Produced by a parent or guardian
  • FEATURES

RELATED TO CHILD

  • Age: < 3 years
  • Sex: More common with male
  • Status: Usually, illegitimate & unwanted children
  • Position: eldest or youngest

RELATED TO PARENTS/ GUARDIAN

  • Status: unmarried couple
  • Age: young
  • Education: Lower level of education
  • childhood History: Parents themselves are the victims of battering during childhood

CLASSICAL FEATURES

  • Discrepancy b/w the natures of injures & explanation offered by parents
  • Gap b/w the injury & medical attention which can’t be explained
  • Different stages of injuries

INJURIES

1. SOFT TISSUES INJURIES

  • Bruises, abrasions & lacerations
  • Laceration of oral mucosa along with labial frenulum of the lower lip (Characteristic features)
  • Slap marks, lash marks, knuckle punches, pinch marks, butterfly bruises & 6 Pennie bruises are seen

2. CNS INJURIES

  • Shaken baby syndrome/ infantile whiplash syndrome
  • Occurs d/t violet shaking of the baby

TRIAD OF INJURIES

  • Encephalopathy
  • Retinal hemorrhages
  • Subdural hemorrhages
    • Most consistent
    • 1st clinical sign of CT scan

3. SKELETAL INJURIES

LONG BONE INJURIES

  • Highly suggestive of BBS
  • Corner fracture →
  • Bucket handle fractures
    • d/t aversion injury in metaphysis

SKULL FRACTURES

  • FISSURE FRACTURED
  • EGG SHELL FRACTURES

RIB INJURIES

  • Fracture at different stages of healing
  • STRING OF BEADS APPEARANCE (CALUS)

4. OTHER INJURIES

VISCERAL INJURIES

  • Injuries to spleen, liver, or hollow viscera

BURNS

  • Small circular pitted burns may indicate deliberate stubbing of cigarette ends on skin
  • Scalds also common

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presented with profuse bleeding from the nose and obstruction. On examination, a fleshy mass was noted in the nasal cavity which started to bleed on touching. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: This is a hypodense, spherical shaped tumor
Endoscopic excision is always the treatment of choice
Posterior bowing of anterior maxillary wall seen on CECT

questions.solution:
Juvenile NasopharyngealAngiofibroma / JNA

  • M/C benign tumor of nasopharynx
  • M/C in young male (Androgen dependent tumor) (8-22 years)
  • Vascular tumor
  • M/C blood supply or JAF → Sphenopalatine artery (Br. Of internal maxillary Artery)
  • Exclusively seen in adolescent males (Androgen dependent tumor) 8-22 yrs

Symptoms

  • No tunica media → Profuse recurrent epistaxis → anemia
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Swelling in cheek ⊕

O/E

  • Reddish polypoid mass → Bleed on touch

FROG – Face deformity

  • Proptosis
  • Tele canthus (Intercanthus length↑, eye ball pushed laterally)

DX

CECT –

  • Anterior bowing of posterior maxillary wall = ANTRAL/ (HOLMAN MILLER sign)
  • Hyperdense, spindle shape tumor – DUMBELL SHAPED TUMOR
  • Widening of pterygo maxillary tunnel – HONDUSA SIGN
  • Biopsy is C/I
  • Rx – RxOC - Endoscopic excision

questions.solution:
The image shows a zepto-laser assisted cataract surgery

Zeptolaser

questions.text:
Which of the following statement is false about chalazion?

Always tender
Infection of meibomian gland
Malignant change to sebaceous cell carcinoma
Also called a tarsal cyst
Diathermy is used for marginal chalazion
questions.solution:
Chalazion= also called tarsal/meibomian cyst.

  • Chronic non infective lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland
  • C/F – round, painless, non-tender swelling of the lid.

Complications-

  • Large chalazion- blurred vision, astigmatism, mechanical ptosis
  • Malignant change to sebaceous cell carcinoma

Rx –

  • Intralesional injection of steroids
  • Transconjunctival incision & curettage
  • Diathermy – better for marginal chalazion

questions.text: Crowding phenomenon is seen in?

Crowding Phenomenon – the patient is able to identify a Snellen chant character with the amblyopic eye when the character is presented in isolation.

A crowding phenomenon is seen in Amblyopia.

  • Amblyopia– loss of vision in a child (<8yr)
  • Lazy eye syndrome
  • M/c/c of amblyopia =squint
  • Best treatment of Amblyopia -occlusion of the good eye- forces the amblyopic eye to see more and thereby develop better vision. Occlusion therapy works only when the development is plastic (i.e., during childhood)
  • Vitaminused for treating Toxic Amblyopia -Hydroxocobalamin(a misnomer - Toxic Optic Neuropathy is a better-used term)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with no relevant past medical history presented to the hospital with severe right-sided retro-orbital pain with right-sided ptosis and diplopia. He also complained of neck stiffness but denied any symptoms of nausea or vomiting. After extensive evaluation, granulomatous inflammation of the superior orbital fissure was identified. The specific term for this condition is:
questions.solution:
Tolosa Hunt Syndrome

  • Specific term used for granulomatous inflammation of superior orbital fissure
  • Painful Ophthalmoplegia
  • Present as either Superior Orbital fissure syndrome/ Orbital apex syndrome

Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome

  • Retro orbital Pain
  • Sensory disturbances in ophthalmic division of 5th nerve
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to 3rd , 4th, 6th nerve
  • Ptosis due to 3rd nerve palsy

Orbital Apex Syndrome

  • Symptom complex produced by involvement of structures passing through superior orbital fissure and optical canal
  • The features are similar to Superior orbital fissure syndrome
  • Features of optic nerve involvement like early visual loss and RAPD are also present

questions.text: A 20-year-old alcoholic malnourished patient presented to the hospital with respiratory distress. His pulse was 112/minute. The patient had edema, hypertension, systolic murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral murmur along the left sternal edge. Bilateral crepitations were felt in the lungs. A diagnosis of congestive high output cardiac failure was made. Which vitamin is deficient?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B 1 – water-soluble vitamin

  • It has a specific coenzyme TPP (thiamine pyrophosphate) which helps in carbohydrate metabolism.
  • TPP Dependent enzyme
  1. pyruvate dehydrogenase - conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA.
  2. alpha -Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase – CTA CYCLE
  3. Transketolase - (HMP shunt)
  4. The branched-chain ALPHA - keto acid dehydrogenase -: oxidative decarboxylation pyrophosphate of branched-chain amino acids.
  • RDA (Recommended dietary allowance)
    • Adult – 1 – 1.5 mg/day
    • Children – 0.7 – 1.2 mg /day
  • The requirement increases in pregnancy and lactation (2 mg/ day), old age, and alcoholism.
  • Deficiency of vitamin b 1 is known as beriberi
  • In adults, two types of beri-beri
  • WET BERI – BERI - This is characterized by edema of legs, face, trunk, and serous cavities.
    • Dyspnoea and palpitation are present
    • The systolic blood pressure is elevated while diastolic is decreased
    • Pulse is fast and bouncing
    • Death is due to heart failure
  • Dry beri-beri - This is associated with neurological manifestations resulting in peripheral neuritis.
    • edema is not seen
    • muscle become week so the patient has difficulty in walking.
  • Infantile beri-beri
    • infant born to a mother who is suffering from thiamine deficiency
    • Breast milk is containing low thiamine
    • Sleeplessness, vomiting, convulsions
    • Bouts of screaming
    • resembles to abdominal colic
    • These all symptoms are due cardiac dilation
    • Death occurs suddenly due to heart failure
  • Wernicke’s encephalopathy
    • Seen in chronic alcoholics
    • insufficient intake or impaired intestinal absorption of thiamine will lead to this syndrome
    • Symptoms of Wernicke’s encephalopathy
  1. G-Global confusion
  2. O-Ophthalmoplegia
  3. A-Ataxia

Korsakoff syndrome – chronic neurological complication

  1. Amnesia - mainly anterograde amnesia
  2. Confabulations – false story and honest lying
  • Thiamine Nutritional Status Can Be Assessed by Erythrocyte Transketolase Activity

questions.text: Which of the given statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Vitamin K is the only fat-soluble vitamin with coenzyme activity
Phylloquinone is derived from a plant source
Vitamin K3 can be converted to Vitamin K1 in liver
Menaquinone is synthesized by bacterial flora in the intestine

questions.solution:
Vitamin K

K → Koagulation/ coagulation

→ Only fat-soluble vitamins with enzyme function

3 forms (2 natural and 1 synthetic) 00:01:00

(K1) Phyloquinone
  • Plant source
(K2) Menaquinone
  • Animal source
  • Synthesized by bacterial flora in intestine
  • Stored in Liver
(K3) synthetic form Menadione
  • Water soluble

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding prenatal diagnostic techniques, except?

choices.text: Pregnant lady is given an undertaking that she does not want to know the sex of the fetus
PNDT is indicated in pregnant women > 35 y.o. and 2 or more spontaneous abortions
Application for renewal of registration has to be made 30 days before expiry and it is valid for 10 years
Appropriate authority for PNDT has the power of cancellation or suspension of registration of clinic/hospital

questions.solution:
POWER OF APPROPRIATE AUTHORITIES

  • Registration of Institutions
  • Seal & Seize
  • Power of search & seize records
  • Cancellation or suspension of registration of Clinic/ Hospital

PNDT IS INDICATED WHEN

  • Age of pregnant women is above 35 years
  • 2 or more spontaneous abortions
  • Pregnant women have been exposed to drugs, radiation, infection, or chemicals
  • Family history of Mental retardation or physical deformities in the previous offspring
  • The pregnant lady gives an undertaking that she does not want to know the sex of the fetus.

RENEWAL OF REGISTRATION

  • The certificate is valid for 5 years.
  • Application for renewal has to be made 30 days before the date of expiry in the prescribed form A.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about the Amniotic fluid index on USG?

choices.text: Oligohydramnios in cord and limb free pocket is <5 cm
Normal amniotic fluid index ranges 1000-2000 ml
Polyhydramnios in cord and limb free pocket is >10 cm

questions.solution:
Amniotic Fluid Index (On USG)

  • Normal Amniotic Fluid Index → 10-15 (range 5-24) (1000 ml)
  • Oligohydramnios → < 5 (< 500 ml)
  • Polyhydramnios → > 25 (> 2000 ml)

Single Pocket Criteria - Cord free & limb free pocket is assessed

  • Oligohydramnios → < 2 cm
  • Polyhydramnios → > 8 cm

questions.text: A G2P1 female presented to the emergency room with complaints of painless bleeding from the vagina. She is pregnant with 28 weeks AOG. On examination, a velamentous cord at Os was seen. What is the best modality for diagnosing this case?
questions.solution:
VELLAMENTOUS CORD

  • Splitting of cord present

VASAPREVIA →Vellamentous Cord at Os

  • Can have fetal bleeding (50% fatal)
  • Painless bleeding

Diagnosis

  • Doppler (Best)

APT TEST (Alkaline denaturation test)

  • Addition of NaOH to vaginal blood in a test tube →causes Alkaline
  • Denaturation
  • Colourless → Maternal blood
  • Stays red → Fetal RBC
  • Helps to distinguish between maternal & Fetal RBC's
  • Qualitative test
  • Fetal RBC's are resistant to Alkaline denaturation

KLIEHAUERBETKE TEST

  • Quantitative test
  • Used to calculate the dose of Anti-D in Rh isoimmunization

SINGER'S TEST

  • Qualitative test
  • Alkaline denaturation test

questions.text: A pregnant woman visited the OPD for a normal antenatal visit. An Ultrasound was taken. Doppler localized an Arterio-venous anastomosis. Which of the following is true regarding the possible diagnosis of this case?

choices.text: Polyhydramnios > 8 cm liquor pocket in recipient
Mortality is 100% if present at or before 24 weeks AOG
Amnioreduction of smaller baby is done as treatment
Oligohydramnios < 4 cm liquor pocket in donor

questions.solution:
Dx OF TTTS

  • MCDA picture on USG
  • Doppler localization of A-Vanastomosis
  • Oligoamnios (<2cm liquor pocket) in Donor
  • Polyhydramnios (>8cm liquor pocket) in Recipient
  • Hb difference → ³ 5gm %
  • Wt. difference →> 20% (Larger twin taken as Index)

Mx of TTTS

  • Mortality d/t TTTS, if present at 26 wks or before →100%
  • Dx is made by USG & Doppler localization of A-Vanastomosis

Rx

  • Laser Ablation of A-Vanastomosis
  • Amnioreduction of larger baby (Poly hydramnios)
  • Single fetal reduction

questions.text: A pregnant lady was screened for GDM at 24 weeks of pregnancy. Glucose tolerance test with 75 grams of sugar in fasting state was 100, at 1 hour was 190 and 2 hour was 150. Which of the following can be a newborn complication?
questions.solution:
Hypoglycaemia

  • Sugar in mother → Reach fetus
  • Fetus has a healthy pancreas which makes increased insulin to metabolize sugars (also there is increased IGF which leads to Macrosomia)
  • When the baby is born → Insulin in baby Leads to Hypoglycaemia
  • There is b-cell pancreatic hyperplasia in the fetus
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Polycythaemia
  • Hyper bilirubinaemia

Anomalies

  • Cataract in newborn
  • Cardiac (MC group of anomalies)
  • Transposition of great vessels (MC & most specific)
  • VSD
  • PDA
  • Neural tube defects
  • Anencephaly
  • Spinal Bifida
  • Facial defects - cleft palate, cleft lip

questions.text: A 27-year-old G1P0 female came for her regular antenatal check-up. As an obstetrician, you wanted to assess the uteroplacental flow of the fetus. Which among the following is the best measure for it?
questions.solution:
Doppler of Blood Vessels

  • Umbilical arteries
  • Uterine Arteries

Ductusvenosus

  • Most important Doppler for assessment Umbilical of Uteroplacental flow is Uterine Artery Doppler
  • Single best measure to assess the Uteroplacental flow →Doppler of DuctusVenosus

questions.text: A primigravida of 12 weeks AOG came for ante natal check-up. There were no complaints of pain or bleeding. On examination, Fetal heart tone was absent. USG was taken. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PRESENTATION OF ABORTION

  • Pain abdomen
  • Bleeding P/V

PV Examination

  • OS closed, Uterine size = POG → Threatened Abortion
  • OS open, products are bulging → Inevitable abortion
  • OS open, Products are felt with H/O passage of some mass →Incomplete Abortion
  • OS closed, H/O passage, normal Uterine size → Complete Abortion

On USG,

  • Cardiac activity Å at 9 weeks
  • Crumpled sac with some fleshy mass inside 12 weeks →Missed abortion
  • No pain & no bleeding
  • Blighted Ovum / Anembryonic Gestation
  • Normally around 7 weeks of gestation, yolk sac is pinched out
  • Pregnancy not gone beyond the stage of sac →Blighted Ovum
  • HIV & Hep-B does not cause Abortion

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the diagnosis of pregnancy using radiological equipment’s, except?

choices.text: Cardiac activity is heard with Transabdominal sonography at 5+ weeks
Fetal heart sound heard with Fetal Doppler at 12 weeks
Gestational sac is seen with Transvaginal sonography at 4+ weeks
Fetal heart sound heard with Stethoscope at 24 weeks

questions.solution:
USG

  • 24 weeks FHS heard with Stethoscope
  • Palpation of Fetal parts from 24th week
  • Fetal movement may be felt during palpation
G-SAC CARDIAC ACTIVITY
  • TVS – 4+ weeks
  • TAS – 5+ weeks
  • 5+ weeks
  • 6+ weeks

questions.text: A pregnant female experienced labor pain at 34 weeks of gestation and was brought to the labor room. All of the following can be a reason for preterm labor when diagnosed with USG, except?
questions.solution:
Uterine Over Distention

USG

questions.text: A G3P3 woman delivered a term baby via normal vaginal delivery and was discharged after 2 days from the hospital. After 2 weeks of delivery, the patient developed fever, abdominal pain, fatigue, and foul-smelling discharge from the vagina. What are the best radiological modalities you will order in this patient to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Abdominal Xray and CT lower limb
CT scan or MRI lower limb
USG of Abdomen and MRI lower limb

questions.solution:
Deep Venous Thrombosis

  • Accompanies the Endometritis

Clinical Features

  • Pain
  • In abdomen or in Limbs
  • Radiating to thigh (if Thrombus is in Pelvic veins)
  • ↑Pulse Rate
  • Fever

Investigations

  • ↑WBC
  • ↑ESR
  • ↑CRP
  • Do CT Scan/MRI →to localize the Thrombus
  • MC cause – Thrombus in deep Pelvic veins

Treatment

  • Strict Bed rest
  • Limited Physiotherapy
  • IV antibiotics (Clindamycin + Gentamycin)
  • Heparin 5000 IU - 10000 IU OD / BID
  • INR should be > 2

questions.text: A patient on examination, showed Uterine tenderness, adnexal tenderness, cervical motion tenderness. Which of the following is not useful in the diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
PELVIC INFLAMMATORY DISEASE- CULTURE & SENSITIVITY OF

  • Endometrial Biopsy
  • Vaginal swab
  • Cervical Swab
  • Culture MEDIAS For GONORRHEA → Thayer martin media
  • CHLAMYDIA → Mc coy cell lines [PCR Preferred]

  • ↑TLC

ELABORATE CRITERIA

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with complaints of mood swings and insomnia. She also developed intense heat with sweating all over her face and chest which becomes normal in a few minutes. What is the drug of choice for the later symptom?
questions.solution:
Rx OF HOT FLUSHES

  • DOC → ESTROGENS takes 20-25 days to act
  • CLONIDINE HYDROCHLORIDE
    • Acute relief
    • 100 µg OD/BD

FLUOXETINE takes 6-7 days

questions.text: Name the procedure indicated in the image, if the dotted line denotes the resected portion.
questions.solution:
• Wertheim’s hysterectomy is also known as Radical hysterectomy.
  • A hysterectomy can be performed through the vagina or the abdomen.
  • Total hysterectomy – The body of the uterus and the cervix are removed.
  • Subtotal hysterectomy – Only the body of the uterus is removed.
  • Radical or Wartheim’s hysterectomy – The uterus, cervix, pelvic lymph nodes, the upper third of the vagina, fallopian tubes and ovaries are removed.

questions.text: A 25 years old G1P1 female from a village presented to the labor room for delivery. It was noted that the patient had no antenatal visits during pregnancy. Despite having good uterine contractions, there was no progress of labor. There was minimal or no descent of presenting part. All of the following can be a cause for these features, except?
questions.solution:
Obstructed Labor

  • No progress of labor inspite of good uterine contractions (i.e. there is no descent of the presenting part)

Causes

  • Neglected Cephalopelvic disproportion (MC)
    • Large baby
    • Contracted Pelvis
  • Malpresentation
    • Transverse Lie with shoulder presentation
    • Neglected Brow presentation
  • Malpositions
    • Occipito-posterior
  • Mx of Obstructed labor → C-section
  • Obstructed labor with dead baby → C-section

questions.text: A mother of four children decided to undergo tubectomy procedure. What is the most commonly performed technique for this procedure?
questions.solution:
TECHNIQUES OF TUBECTOMY

Pomeroy Techniques

  • Most commonly done
  • Single ligature is used
  • Tube cut end are together Can lead to fistula formation

POMEROY PROCEDURE

Parkland Technique

  • Double ligature is used
  • Tubes are ligated separately

PARKLAND

Irwing Procedure

  • One end of tube is anastomosed into uterine musculature
  • Other end of tube is anastomosed into mesosalpinx

IRWING

Sub Mucosal Dissection of Tube (UCHIDA’S Procedure)

Serosa is lifted by needle & saline is injected

  • Then serosa is incised and tube is resected
  • Serosa is sutured again
  • Fibrosis & adhesions are very less, as cut ends are within the serosa.

UCHIDA’S

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was brought by her parents complaining of the absence of menstrual onset. On examination, there was the presence of menstrual blood and a diagnosis of Cryptomenorrhea was made. All of the following can be a cause of this condition, except?
questions.solution:
CRYPTOMENORRHEA

  • Menstruation present [Hematometra-blood in uterus; Hematocolpos - blood in vagina] but menstrual blood not coming out
  • Transverse vaginal septum
  • Vaginal atresia
  • Cervical vaginal atresia
  • Imperforate hymen

VERTICAL FUSION DEFECTS

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with pubertal features. During a regular check-up, he was diagnosed as a case of precocious puberty and several workups were done. It was noted that the patient had deficiency of 21 hydroxylase enzyme. What is the condition present in this patient?
questions.solution:
CONGENITAL ADRENAL HYPERPLASIA (CAH)

  • Due to deficiency of 21 Hydroxylase enzyme

1. Classical variety

  • Boy → Precocious puberty
  • In Girl → AMBIGUOUS GENITALIA, Penis & scrotum present, No testes.

2. In salt loosing variety

  • ↓ Na+
  • ↓ H2O
  • ↑ K+
  • Fatal to the baby [boy or girl]

3. Late onset/ Adult onset Adrenal Hyperplasia

Rx by long term steroids

  • MC cause of CAH → 21 β hydroxylase deficiency
  • 2nd mc cause of CAH → 11 β hydroxylase deficiency
  • PREVENTION - Start the steroid at the time of Dx of next pregnancy
  • GENETIC MALE & PHENOTYPIC FEMALE - MALE PSEUDO HERMAPHRODITE
  • GENETIC FEMALE & PHENOTYPIC MALE - FEMALE PSEUDO HERMAPHRODITE

EXAMPLES OF

  • MALE PSEUDO HERMAPHRODITE → TFS
  • FEMALE PSEUDO HERMAPHRODITE → CAH
  • TRUE HERMAPHRODITE

MALE + FEMALE KARYOTYPE & MALE + FEMALE GONADS → OVOTESTIS & MALE + FEMALE EXTERNAL GENITALIA

questions.text: An 18 year old female complained of pain in the pelvis every month for the past few months. Upon evaluation, it was noted that the pain was due to collection of blood and debris in the pouch of Douglas at the time of ovulation. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MITTLESHMERZ/ MID CYCLE PAIN - d/t blood & debris (from the follicle) collected into Pouch of Douglas at the time of ovulation

DYSMENORRHEA (Pain of Menstruation)

  • During ovulation, Prostaglandins are released (d/t rupture of oocyte).
  • This causes contractions of uterine muscle to allow cervix to open for passage of shredded endometrium (by action of PG’s from CL).
  • These contractions cause pain.

TYPES

PRIMARY/SPASMODIC DYSMENORRHEA

  • Pain starts 30 min before onset of periods and stays 10 hrs post onset
  • Seen in normal women, women with fibroids

CONGESTIVE / SECONDARY DYSMENORRHEA

  • Pain starts 3-4 days prior and stays throughout menses
  • seen in PID & endometriosis

MEMBRANUOSDYSMENORRHEA

  • Fibrinolytic system in uterus is responsible for less/ non clumping of blood

questions.text: A newly married couple presented with complaints of Infertility. Having no significant history causing the problem, semen analysis was performed which showed absence of sperm. Ovulation tests showed normal results. Which among the sperm extraction techniques that should be performed in this patient, is suitable to be done under general anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
AZOOSPERMIA [Obstructive azoospermia]

  • Normal FSH & azoospermia → obstructive azoospermia
  • SPERM EXTRACTION TECHNIQUE

PESA [percutaneousepididymal sperm aspiration]

TESA [Testicular sperm aspiration]

  • Both can be done under local anaesthesia
  • Both are simple techniques [needle aspiration]

MESA [ Micro surgical epididymal sperm aspiration]

TESA [Testicular sperm extraction]

  • Both are done under GA
  • Both are complicated techniques

questions.text: A 70 year old female presented with vulvar mass. On examination, the mass was already a significant part of lower 1/3rd of urethra. No lymph nodes were involved. What would be the treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
STAGING

STAGE I Limited to Vulva

I A

I B

Size →> 2 cm, invasion > 1mm
STAGE II Adjacent organ involvement

Lower 1/3 rd vagina

Lower 1/3 rd of urethra Anus
STAGE III Inguino femoral LN involvement

Aii

One LN → > 5 mm

One or two LN → < 5 mm

III Bi

Bii

More than 3 LN → < 5 mm
III C LN involvement Å, with extra capsular spread
STAGE IV

IV Ai

Aii

Upper urethra, upper vagina, rectal involvement, growth stuck to pelvic bone

Fixed or ulcerated LN
IV B Distant metastasis Pelvic LN

Treatment

STAGE I A

Limited to Vulva

Invasion < 1mm

Wide Local Incision + Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy

questions.text: A 50 year old farmer was brought by his son to the emergency department with symptoms of dyspnea, increased sweating, lacrimation, involuntary urination. Upon examination, Miosis was noted. H.R – 54 bpm. Which of the following drug poisonings can be treated with dialysis?
questions.solution:
• For some drugs antidote can be given
  • Many drugs don’t have antidote, so dialysis is the option in those poisoning
  • Dialysis is effective only if the drug is staying in the plasma (bcoz plasma is filtered in dialysis). So, for the dialysis to be effective, the drug should have
  • ↓ volume of distribution (Vd)
  • ↓ plasma protein binding (PDB)
  • ↓ PPB doesn’t always cause ↑ Vd; sometimes there can be ↓ Vd due to other factors like ↓ tissue affinity of that drug etc)

Drugs in which dialysis is done

  • M → Methanol
  • L → Lithium
  • A → Aspirin

Drugs in which dialysis is not effective

  • A → Amphetamines
  • V → Verapamil
  • O → Opioids & organophosphates
  • I → Imipramine
  • D → Digoxin
  • Dialysis → Diazepam (Most of benzodiazepines)

questions.text: An adolescent after having mushrooms for dinner, presented with sweating, bradycardia, and increased salivation. What is the next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
POISONING DOC
Organophosphates & Carbamate Atropine
Atropa Belladonna /Datura Physostigmine
Early Mushroom Poisoning Atropine

MUSHROOM POISONING
Early Mushroom Poisoning Late Mushroom poisoning
  • Caused by Inocybe / Clitocybe species
  • Caused by Amanita group of species
  • Shows symptoms similar to Organophosphate poisoning
  • DOC – Atropine
  • It is also Known as Hallucinogenic Mushroom poisoning
  • Shows symptoms similar to Atropine poisoning
  • Atropine is C/I
  • Management is purely symptomatic

questions.text: A middle-aged businessman presented with chronic compensated congestive heart failure along with Gout. Which of the following drugs will be useful in this patient?

ARBs [Angiotensin (AT1) Receptors Blockers]

  • Valsartan A → At1
  • Telmisartan R → Receptor
  • Irbesartan T

  • Candesartan N

Telmisartan

  • Used to Reverse Insulin Resistance

Losartan

  • cause ↓ in uric acid

questions.text: A 60-year-old headmaster of a school went with his students to a hill station for yearly tour. After reaching the destination, he started to experience dyspnea and hyperventilation was noted. He was then taken to the nearest clinic, where he was prescribed Acetazolamide. All of the following are adverse effects of this drug which the doctor will address, except?
questions.solution:
Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors

  • Acts on Proximal tubule
  • Inhibits carbonic anhydrase
  • causes Loss of Na+ & HCO3- in urine
  • ↓ Na+ +H2O → Diuresis
  • ↓ HCO3- →Urinary Metabolic alkalosis

Self-limiting action includes

  • Acetazolamide - given as eye drops
  • Brinzolamide - given as eye drops
  • Dorzolamide

  • Acetazolamide → can be given orally/injectable form

Indications

  • Glaucoma (Angle-closure glaucoma)
  • Alkalinization of urine
  • Mountain Sickness [DOC]
  • Epilepsy

Adverse Effects

  • Metabolic Acidosis
  • Hypokalaemia [Max: Hypokalaemia among diuretics]
  • Paraesthesia
  • Renal Stones

Contra-indication

  • Liver disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a past history of myocardial infarction and currently on treatment with Atenolol, Losartan and Clopidogrel presented with acute exacerbation of asthma. Which drug will you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
M3 Blockers → Ipratropium, Tiotropium

  • Given by inhalational route
  • DOC for the acute attack in patients on β blocker therapy
  • Salbutamol and Terbutaline are short-acting beta 2 agonists which cannot be effective in a patient with beta-blocker therapy.
  • Theophylline has a lot of adverse effects.
DUE TO PDE INHIBITION DUE TO ADENOSINE A1 ANTAGONISM
GIT: Nausea, Vomiting, Diarrhea Diuresis
Headache Seizures
Arrhythmias Arrhythmias

questions.text: A final-year medical student presented with a stomach ache. History revealed that the patient had a chronic intake of Aspirin for pain due to an injury in his legs. A differential diagnosis of Peptic ulcer was made. What is the most specific drug for NSAID-induced Peptic ulcers?

M1 blockers H2 blockers PGE2 PPI

 Misoprostol

questions.text: There are a handful of drugs for Non-insulin-dependent Diabetes mellitus. Out of the following drugs belonging to different groups, choose the most appropriate drug that needs cardiac function monitoring after administration.
questions.solution:
Glitazones (Thiazolidinediones)

S/E

  • Hepatotoxic
  • Max. hepatoxicity → Troglitazone [withdrawn]
  • Rosiglitazone & Pioglitazone requires LFT monitoring
  • Na+ & water Retention → avoid in CHF & HTN
  • ↑ risk of MI by ROSIGLITAZONE
  • ↑ risk of urinary bladder carcinoma by Pioglitazone

Biguanides – Phenformin → is more a/w Lactic Acidosis [not used now]

GLPanalogues – Liraglutide

  • Approved for obesity Rx
  • Risk of hypoglycaemia is very less (compared to other insulin-releasing drugs)

Side effects

  • Acute pancreatitis (major side effect)
  • Nausea (most common)
  • Increased risk of Medullary carcinoma of Thyroid

DPP4 inhibitors – Linagliptin Side effects:

  • Nasopharyngitis (most common)
  • Pancreatitis

Contraindications:

  • Gliptins are contraindicated in renal failure except for Linagliptin which is safe in renal failure

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with sleeplessness for three days already. Further history revealed that he was later in a relationship that broke up and he works in a company for 12 hours a day. What will be the suitable drug to be prescribed for this patient?
questions.solution:
Z Drugs → Zolpidem, Zopiclone, Zaleplon, Eszopiclone

  • Stimulates α1/ω1 subunit of Benzodiazepine receptor
  • Only ↓ Latency
  • Does not ↓ the duration of sleep
  • Lack anti-anxiety, Muscle relaxant, Anticonvulsant properties (unlike benzodiazepines)
  • Only hypnotic property (+)
  • Antidote is Flumazenil
  • No hangover
  • No sleep quality compromised
  • Non-addictive
  • Drug of choice for Insomnia

questions.text: A patient with risk of MI was given orally a direct thrombin inhibitor. After a few minutes, the patient started to bleed through his nose. What will be the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Direct Thrombin Inhibitors:

  • Dabigatran – can be given Orally and does not require monitoring
  • Dabigatron overdose/toxicity is treated with a monoclonal antibody called Idarucizumab
  • Andexanet alpha is the antidote for factor Xa inhibitor overdose.
  • Active Factors like IIa, VLLa, IXa, Xa (which are Known as Four Factor complex (or) Prothrombin Factor complex) is the Treatment of choice.
  • If Four Factor complex is not available, then fresh frozen plasma can be used.
  • If the fresh frozen plasma is also not available, Whole blood should be given.
  • But the Treatment of choice for bleeding tendency due to warfarin is Vitamin K. It is also the antidote for Warfarin overdose.

questions.text: Tetracyclines act by inhibiting the attachment of tRNA to A site of mRNA, thus inhibiting the synthesis of proteins. This group of drugs is the drug of choice for many diseases, except which of the following?
questions.solution:
Uses of TETRACYCLINES

  • S → SIADH [Demeclocycline]
  • R → Rickettsia [DOC]
  • I → Granuloma Inguinale [DOC]
  • L → LGV
  • A Atypical pneumonia [DOC → Macrolides]
  • N

questions.text: Meta analysis is the analysis of multiple studies together. It provides point estimate of Effect size. All of the following are limitations of this method, except?
questions.solution:
• Berkesonian bias is based on location and reputation of an institute.
  • It is a type of Investigator bias.
  • It is not a limitation of Meta analysis

Limitations of Meta-analysis:

1. Garbage In Garbage Out (GIGO)

  • Ultimately the quality of the study depends on the studies chose by the researcher for inclusion for review in the meta-analysis (if the original quality of the studies were bad then the outcome will also be bad quality)

2. Apples & oranges effect

  • The researcher tend to match Different study types, different study locations, different type of study results into one result together, sometimes not every parameters are comparable or synthesizable.

3. File Drawer effect / Publication Bias

  • If the researcher has found 96 cohort studies for smoking, Lung cancer for conducting or doing or undertaking a meta-analysis but there can be 10 more studies which the researcher cannot locate or there was 20 more unpublished data which he wasn't able to locate.
  • There may always be some missing studies which will lead to asymmetry funnel plot which indicate publication bias or systematic heterogeneity in this study.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presented with persistent thrombocytopenia from birth. He was initially diagnosed as ITP and was started on IVIG. His clinical condition continued to deteriorate with recurrent infections and eczema. Molecular analysis confirmed Wiskott Aldrich syndrome. Which of the following is true about Wiskott Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is due to wasp gene mutation.

Option 1

B CELL DISORDERS

  • Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia / X-linked agammaglobulinemia: defect in B tyrosine Kinase gene
  • X Linked Hyper IgM Syndrome: Deficiency of CD 40 Ligand on activated T cells.
  • Selective IqA Deficiency: Leads to repeated sino pulmonary infections
  • Common Variable Immunodeficiency: B CELLS present in blood, decreased immunoglobulins.
  • Transient Hypogammaglobulinemia: delayed onset of normal IgG synthesis

Option 2

T CELL DEFECTS

  • Di George Syndrome :
    • chromosome 22 q11 deletion.
    • absence thymus & para thyroid glands.
    • hypoparathyroidism.
    • congenital heart defects.
    • Chronic Mucucutaneous candidiasis: causes recurrent candidiasis.

Option 3

Features of Wiskott Aldrich syndrome:

  • X linked Recessive disease.
  • Combined B and T cell disorder.
  • WASP gene defect.
  • Low IgM.
  • Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is a triad of
  • Recurrent infections
  • thrombocytopenia
  • eczema.

Option 4

DISORDERS OF PHAGOCYTOSIS:

  • CGD (chronic Granulomatous Disease): deficiency of NADPH oxidase.
  • LAD syndrome (Leukocyte adhesion deficiency): defect of CD 18 (β subunit of integrins).
  • Chediak Higashi syndrome: Defective phagolysomal fusion.
  • Job syndrome/ Hyper IgE syndrome: deficiency of TH 17 cells.
  • MPO Deficiency: Myeloperoxidase deficiency.

questions.text: Regarding the transport of Ca++ across a membrane, which of the following is true?

choices.text: Maintains a high intracellular Ca++ concentration

questions.solution:
Calcium transport occurs by secondary active transport. Hence, option A is incorrect

It is an antiport or counter transport, occurring as Na+/ Ca++ exchanger. Hence, option B is incorrect

It is primarily aimed at maintaining a low cytosolic Ca++. Thus, option C is incorrect.

To maintain a low intracytoplasmic Ca++, calcium is extruded out of the cell or pumped out from cytosol into the endoplasmic reticulum.

Primary active transporter at the plasma membrane is present in most if not all cells which extrude Ca2+ from the cell called PMCA. In the P2B subfamily of P-type ATPases, at least four PMCA isoforms appear.

For each molecule of ATP that is hydrolyzed, these pumps exchange one H+ for one Ca2+.

Ca2+ ATPase - The enzyme that transports Ca2+ out of the cytoplasm and into the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells. These are called P-type ATPases because they form a key phosphorylated intermediate.

ZONES OF BLOOD FLOW IN LUNGS

(Not Fixed, they can change)

  • Created d/t interplay of Hydrostatic Factor (pressure) & alveolar pressure

Alveolar Pressure vessel pressure

  • Compresses vessels— ↓ Blood Flow
  • Present at the apex of Lungs
  • Vessel pressure > Alveolar Pressure
    • Present at base of Lungs
    • Can't compress the vessels

Zone I

  • No blood Glow
  • Pa/v > Part > Pvein

Zone Il

  • Intermittent blood flow
  • Partcop > PA/V > Pvein
  • During systole, blood flow during diastole, ↓ blood flow

Zone III

  • Continuous blood flows
  • Part > Pvein > Palveoli
  • In IPPV / Assisted ventilation
    • ↑ P Alveoli
    • Zone III → Zone II
    • Zone II → Zone I

questions.text: Which of the following is Pin Index system for CO2?
Which of the following is the best drug for cerebroprotective action?
questions.solution:
Barbiturates cause a dose related decrease in cerebral oxygen consumption rate, rate of ATP consumption thus are cerebroprotective. Barbiturates reduce the metabolic activity concerned with neuronal signalling and impulse traffic, not the metabolic activity corresponding to basal metabolic function.

When the EEG became isoelectric, Thiopentone decrease upto 50% of baseline in Cerebral metabolic activity

Propofol is neuroprotective against ischemic injury but only if the ischemic insult is mild and not sustained. The neuroprotective effect results from attenuation of changes in ATP, calcium, sodium and potassium caused by hypoxic injury Ketamine increases cerebral blood flow, cerebral metabolism and intracranial pressure.

Ketamine increases cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen due to its excitatory CNS effects which can be detected by generalised theta wave activity in EEG and petit mal seizure like activity in hippocampus

Etomidate reduces cerebral blood blow by 34% and cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen by 45% without altering mean arterial pressure. Cerebral perfusion pressure is maintained or increased and a beneficial net increase in cerebral oxygen supply to demand ratio occurs. Etomidate also reduces intracranial pressure to 50% in patients with already increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient who is a case of mitral stenosis posted for mitral valve replacement surgery. The patient induced with Inj. Fentanyl 10 mcg/kg and Inj. Thiopentone 100 mg intravenously. The anaesthesiologist was not able to do mask ventilation after induction. Inj. Vecuronium 6 mg Iv given and mask ventilation followed by intubation done. Probable reason for this is-
questions.solution: Rapid administration of larger doses of opioids (particularly fentanyl, sufantanyl, Remifentanil and alfentanyl) can induce generalised skeletal muscle rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag and mask ventilation. Although termed chest wall rigidity, majority of resistance to ventilation is due to laryngeal musculature contraction. This is due to striatal release of gamma amino butyric acid and increased dopamine production explains the opioid induced increased skeletal muscle tone. Treatment is muscle relaxation with neuromuscular blockade or opioid antagonism with naloxone.

questions.text: All are true about total intravenous anaesthesia (TIVA) except?

choices.text: The best combination of TIVA is Propofol + Remifentanil
TIVA has better recovery profile with reduced risk of post-operative nausea + vomiting
It can be used safety in patients with risk of malignant hyperthermia
There is no evidence of awareness with TIVA

questions.solution:
Awareness is a significant problem associated with TIVA though mostly due to device problem.

Remifentanil with propofol produces excellent Total Intravenous Anaesthesia (TIVA)

Remifentanil produces analgesia, hemodynamic stability, blunting the response to noxious stimuli Remifentanil has very short duration of action to provide smooth induction and rapid emergence

Propofol provides hypnosis, amnesia and it is antiemetic so there is low incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting

Can be safely used in the patient susceptible to malignant hyperpyrexia as triggering drugs such as volatile anaesthetics and succinylcholine are avoided in TIVA (propofol with remifentanil)

It causes reduction in operation theatre pollution and thus the greenhouse effect of inhalational anaesthesia The paralysis is not always required, avoiding reversal agents and emergence is rapid (especially when propofol TIVA is used with remifentanil)

questions.text: Mother brings her an year old child to the dermatologist as soon as she notices a dramatic color change longitudinally into a pale upper half and a deep red dependent half when she laid down the child on one side. Which of the following is not incorrect statement about this color change?

choices.text: The skin of entire body is typically reddish
Probably reflects an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism

questions.solution:
Harlequin color change: reflects an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. When the infant is placed on the side, the body is bisected longitudinally into a pale upper half and a deep red dependent half. Need no treatment

NOTE: Do not confuse it with Harlequin ichthyosis.

The newborn is covered with thick patches of skin that crack and split. Thickplaques can pull and distort facial features and restrict breathing and foodintake. Mutations in the ABCA12 gene.

questions.text: Among the spontaneously aborted fetuses, autosomal trisomies are the most common chromosomal cause. Which among the following is the most common trisomy encountered in spontaneously aborted fetuses?
questions.solution:
Among the spontaneously aborted foetuses, autosomal trisomies are the most common chromosomal cause. Within this category, trisomy 16 is the most frequent

The recurrence risk of trisomy 16 is negligible in subsequent pregnancies

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was admitted to the ward with complaints of fever for 2 weeks duration. After admission his fever pattern is recorded (shown below). In addition, he has arthritis and hepatosplenomegaly. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The depicted fever pattern is suggestive of Quotidian fever.
  • Quotidian fever means the presence of daily fever spikes with temperature touching and going below baseline (37ºC ) on occasions.
  • Among the given options, clinical history and this fever pattern is suggestive of Systemic onset JIA.
  • Systemic JIA (sJIA):
  • Usually begins as an intermittent fever with a characteristic twice daily peak
  • Evanescent maculopapular truncal rash
  • Arthritis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Serositis (pericarditis or pleuritis)
  • Elevated ESR, Thrombocytosis
  • Rheumatoid factor - Negative
  • Other Options:
    • Measles: common in preschool children; fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion, dry cough, Koplik spots on 2nd or 3rd day of illness, rash on the fourth day with rise in fever.
    • Enteric fever: The hallmark of enteric fever is fever which starts as a low grade fever and then shows stepwise increase peaking to as high as 103-104°C by the end of the first week; fever is associated with malaise, anorexia, nausea; coated tongue, hepatosplenomegaly
    • Acute leukemia: Pallor, fatigue, petechiae, purpura or bleeding, infections, lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, bone pain and tenderness

questions.text:
Mark the correct answers regarding premature closure of sutures.

Dolichocephaly - (A) Closure of Sagittal suture 
Brachycephaly - (B) Closure of Bilateral coronal sutures 
Trigonocephaly - (C) Metopic suture 
Posterior Plagiocephaly - (D) Lambdoid suture
questions.solution:
• craniosynostosis is The most common form of premature closure of the sagittal suture, giving a scaphocephalic (boat-shaped) or dolichocephalic head.
  • Premature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, either major/minor, is called CRANIOSYNOSTOSIS.

Forms of craniosynostosis

  • Trigonocephaly - Metopic suture
  • Brachycephaly - Bilateral coronal sutures
  • Left anterior plagiocephaly - Left coronal suture
  • Right anterior plagiocephaly - Right coronal suture
  • Scaphocephaly - Sagittal suture
  • Right posterior plagiocephaly - Right lambdoid suture
  • Left posterior plagiocephaly - Left lambdoid suture
  • Cloverleaf skull deformity - Caused by fusion of multiple sutures; associated with hydrocephalus
  • Tower skull or acrocephaly - Combined sagittal, coronal, and lambdoid synostosis, often as part of Apert or Crouzon syndrome

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about acute PSGN (Post Streptococcal glomerulonephritis)?

Electron dense humps on GBM 
PSGN following streptococcal skin infection will usually show ASO titer positive 
Renal biopsy is indicated if prolonged hypocomplementemia persists beyond 2 months 
C3 is low in acute phase & returns to normal in 6 – 8 weeks
questions.solution:
• In PSGN, ASO titer is increased in more than 80% of patients following streptococcal sore throat; anti-DNase B is elevated in cases of streptococcal skin infection.
  • The level of serum C3 is low in 90% of patients but normalizes by 6-8 weeks.
  • Persistent low C3 levels indicate other forms of GN and require a renal biopsy On electron microscope, electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are found on the epithelial side of the glomerular basement membrane Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): It is a classic example of an acute nephritic syndrome characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. PSGN follows infection of the throat or skin by certain “nephritogenic” strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. (Throat serotypes - M1, M4, M25, and some strains of M12 and skin serotype - M49) Poststreptococcal GN usually affects school-age children (5-12 years of age) and is uncommon below 3 years of age.

Lab Diagnosis of PSGN:

  • Anti-streptolysin O titer is commonly increased after a pharyngeal infection but rarely increases after streptococcal skin infections. Best single antibody to document cutaneous streptococcal infection is anti deoxyribonuclease (DNase) B level
  • The serum C3 level is significantly decreased in >90% of patients and returns to normal 6-8 wk after onset. (Some authors say that it takes 8-12 weeks for C3 levels to come back to normal) C4 is most often normal.
  • Serum CH50 is commonly depressed A biopsy is rarely indicated when: renal function is severely impaired beyond 7-10 days serum C3 remains depressed beyond 12 weeks Patient with features of a systemic illness Management of PSGN involves: Symptomatic & supportive therapy (treating the acute effects of renal insufficiency and hypertension)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy underwent neurosurgery for cranio­pharyngioma following which multiple pituitary functions were lost. Which of the following hormone should be re­placed first?
questions.solution:
• Hydrocortisone should be supplemented first in hypopituitarism
  • Hypopituitarism: Underproduction of growth hormone (GH) alone or in combination with other pituitary hormones
  • Causes of hypopituitarism

Genetic Causes

    • HESX1 gene
    • PROP-1 gene
    • LHX3 gene
    • LHX4 gene
    • PITX2 gene
    • POU1F1 gene
    • Acquired causes:
    • Idiopathic
    • Brain damage
    • Irradiation
    • Neurosurgery
    • Trauma
    • Tumors
    • Pituitary adenoma
    • Craniopharyngioma
    • Glioma
    • Pinealoma
    • Other causes
    • Inflammation (Histiocytosis)
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Autoimmune Hypophysitis

Order in which pituitary hormones are usually affected: GH > Gonadotropins > TSH > ACTH

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents with precocious puberty, some bony lesions & hyperpigmented skin lesions as shown below.

What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The history & image given in question suggests the diagnosis of McCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME:

McCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME:

  • Characterized by Triad of
    • Precocious puberty
    • Café-au-lait spots
    • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Occurs due to somatic activating mutation of stimulatory G-protein
  • Associated endocrine abnormalities are:
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Rickets
    • GH excess
    • Precocious puberty

Other options:

  • Cushing syndrome: Short stature, central obesity, striae, hypertension, delayed puberty, hirsutism, muscle weakness
  • Prader-Willi syndrome: Intellectual disability, short stature, obesity, hypotonia, hypogonadism
  • Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome: Hypogonadotropichypogonadism, delayed puberty, mental retardation, obesity, polydactyly, retinitispigmentosa

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding chromosomal disorders?

Differential expression of the same gene depending on the parent of origin is referred to as Genomic imprinting 
Prader Willi syndrome - microdeletion on the paternal side 
Angelman syndrome - microdeletion on the maternal side 
2 cell lines with 47 & 45 chromosomes are observed in the same individual is known as Mosaicism
questions.solution:
• Genomic imprinting: Differential expression of the same gene depending on the parent of origin. Ex- PraderWilli syndrome (microdeletion on paternal side or inheritance of both copies of chromosome 15 from the maternal side) & Angelman syndrome (microdeletion on maternal side or inheritance of both copies of chromosome 15 from paternal side).
  • Mosaicism- 2 cell lines with 47 & 45 chromosomes are observed in the same individual.
  • Anticipation- disease manifestation worsen from 1 generation to next
  • Non-penetrance- the state in which a genetic trait fails to manifest itself in the phenotype

questions.text: All of the following are the negative symptoms of Schizophrenia except?
questions.solution:
• Anhedonia - lack of pleasure in a previously pleasurable activity
  • Ambivalence-simultaneous and contradictory attitudes or feelings towards an object/person

Negative symptoms in Schizophrenia are (Anderson's 7A's):

  • Apathy - Lack of concern
  • Avolition - Loss of drive for goal directed activities
  • Asociality - Lack of social interaction
  • Affective flattening or blunting
  • Alogia - Lack of speech output
  • Anhedonia- Lack of pleasure in previously pleasurable activities.
  • Attention deficit - inability to pay attention
  • The more the negative symptoms in an individual with Schizophrenia, the worse is the prognosis.

questions.text: All of the following are seen in post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), EXCEPT :
questions.solution:
• It is a simple question if we understand the differentiation between neurotic and psychotic illness.
  • PTSD is a neurotic disorder
  • Hallucinations are a psychotic symptom
  • Depression is the only illness that comes under neurotic illnesses but can develop psychotic symptoms .

PTSD is characterized by:

  1. Intrusive symptoms- Re experiencing trauma in form of flashback, vivid dreams, nightmares
  2. Avoidance
  3. Arousal symptoms- Hypervigilance, insomnia, exaggerated startle response ,Emotional numbing and Anhedonia .

Symptoms must last for 1 month to diagnose as PTSD.

NOTE: Neurotic patients- judgement ,insight and contact with reality is intact unlike in psychotic disorders.

HOW TO REMEMBER: alcoholic pa-RAN-oia = wife RAN away (morbid jealousy)

questions.text: Clinical reports suggest that subcortical syndromes involve less severe intellectual and memory dysfunction and lack the aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia typical of the cortical dementias . All are causes of subcortical dementia except:
questions.solution:
Alzheimer’s disease is a cortical dementia.

  • Cortical Dementia - Early presentation of 4 As (Amnesia, Apraxia, Aphasia, Agnosia) eg. Alzheimer disease, Creutzfeldt Jacob disease ,Picks disease
  • Subcortical Dementia - Involves Sub cortical structures (Basal ganglia, Cerebellum ) Eg. Parkinson disease, Wilson disease, Huntington disease

HOW TO REMEMBER : It's a commonly known thing that Alzheimer's disease patients have cortical atrophy.

questions.text: A 40 yr old diabetic man comes with a complaint of inability to bend his ring finger and development small nodules on the palm. What will be not be a part of your management in this patient?

choices.text: When more than 30-degree flexion deformity involved at PIP: Subtotal fasciectomy
When more than 30-degree flexion deformity involved at MCP: Subtotal fasciectomy

questions.solution:
This is a condition of Dupuytren's contracture

  • Flexion deformity- because of abnormal fibrosis of palmar aponeurosis leading to cord or nodule formation.
  • M/C cause is Idiopathic
  • MCP>PIP>DIP involved most commonly
  • Ring finger more common than little finger involved

Treatment:

  • Conservative by stretching and inj. collagenase
  • When more than 30 degree involved at MCP and more than 15-20 degree at PIP subtotal fasciectomy is done

questions.text:
Match the following terms with their true meaning-



Terms



1- Spondylitis
a-Pathological fusion of joint


2- Arthrodesis
b-Age related degeneration of the spinal vertebrae ,joints and discs.


3-Spondylolysis
c- Inflammation of the vertebrae.


4- Ankylosis
d-Surgical fusion of joint
questions.solution:
• Spondylitis- Inflammation of the vertebrae.
  • Arthrodesis- Surgical fusion of joints as done in ankle arthrodesis in ankle arthritis.
  • Ankylosisis pathological fusion of joint due to chronic infection or inflammation which is not managed and so infection persists in the joint. e.g., Tuberculosis, Ankylosing Spondylitis.
  • Spondylolysisis a general term used for age related wear and tear of the spinal vertebrae, joints and discs.
  • Spondylolisthesis- it is slippage of disc and compression of neural structures occurs which leads to neural deficit and bowel bladder disturbances in the patient.

questions.text: 12-year-old boy presents with progressive swellings at upper end of tibia – irregular, local temperature raised, invariable consistency and ill defined margins most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation in question can occur both in Ewing’s sarcoma and osteosarcoma.
  • However, swelling is around the knee joint at upper end of tibia, which favours the diagnosis of osteosarcoma (metaphyseal lesion).
  • Ewing’s sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft).
  • Giant cell Tumor site- Epiphysis
  • Secondary metastasis occurs in old age usually.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male underwent liver transplantation for primary sclerosing cholangitis. Post-transplant, the patient had normal liver parameters. Eight weeks later, the patient presented with abdominal pain and jaundice. His liver function tests were found to be elevated. Biopsy revealed graft rejection. Which of the following statements regarding the rejection of solid organ transplants is true?

choices.text: Hyperacute rejection begins in the operating room with reperfusion of the transplanted organ
Liver transplants are especially susceptible to hyperacute rejection
Most immunosuppressive medications are used to prevent chronic rejection
The major cause of graft failure is acute rejection

questions.solution:
Transplant Rejection
Type Onset Mechanism & Vessel Histology Type of Hypersensitivity
Hyperacute ImmediateMinutes to days Preformed antibodies directed against the donor tissue. Caused by accidental ABO blood type incompatibility which is very rare. Presents while still in surgery with thrombosis and occlusion of graft vessels II
Acute Weeks to months T-cell mediated immune response directed against the foreign MHC. Inflammation and leukocyte infiltration of graft vessels results. Most common type IV
Chronic Months to years T-cell mediated process resulting from the foreign MHC "looking like" a self MHC carrying an antigen. Results in intimal thickening and fibrosis of graft vessels as well as graft atrophy III & IV
Graft vs. Host Varies Donor T-cells in the graft proliferate and attack the recipient's tissue. Most commonly seen in bone marrow transplants. Presents with diarrhoea, rash and jaundice IV

Chronic rejection is the most common cause of graft failure after all solid organ transplants

Most immunosuppressive agents are given to prevent acute rejection

The most critical time for immunoprotection is the first few days to months after transplantation because

  • The graft is fresh
  • There is a heightened state of inflammation secondary to inevitable graft injury from ischemia reperfusion as well as the physical transfer of the organ itself

questions.text: Patient was brought to the surgery OPD with complaint of acute abdominal pain, vomiting, fever and bloody stools. After thorough physical examination he was suspected to have Mesenteric Vein Thrombosis. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
MESENTERIC VEIN THROMBOSIS (MVT)

  • Responsible for 5-15% cases of acute mesenteric ischemia
  • Veins involved- Superior mesenteric vein (MC)
  • Inferior mesenteric vein is spared

Clinical features

1. Abdominal pain (most common)

↓ Characteristic features

  • Out of proportion of physical examination findings
  • Persists for 2-3 hrs

2. Melena and Hematochezia-15%

Diagnosis

  • Investigation of choice- CECT

Management

  • Rapid initiation of systemic anticoagulants
    • Heparin- used intra-operatively
    • Anticoagulation- Should be continued post operatively (as risk of recurrence is 35-70%)
  • In case of peritonitis – Exploratory laparotomy (mortality rate- upto 50%)

questions.text: A 53-year-old male was brought the ER with pain abdomen and bloody diarrhoea. On barium enema ‘Thumb print sign’ was noted. The physician treated the patient by advising bowel rest and brad spectrum anti-biotics. The most common site of this condition is?
questions.solution:
Ischemic colitis

  • Results from low flow or small vessel occlusion
  • Risk factors
    • vascular disease
    • diabetes mellitus
    • hypotension
    • tobacco use
    • ligation of inferior mesenteric artery during aortic surgery
  • Most common site of ischemic colitis- splenic flexure
  • Rectum - relatively spared
  • Signs and symptoms
  • Mild - bloody diarrhoea
  • Severe - abdominal pain, tenderness, fever and leucocytosis
  • Diagnosis
    • Plain films - thumb printing due to mucosal edema and submucosal haemorrhage
    • CT - nonspecific colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding
    • Sigmoidoscopy - characteristic dark haemorrhagic mucosa
  • Bowel rest and broad-spectrum antibiotics are the mainstay of therapy
  • Long term sequelae include stricture and chronic segmental ischemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old with long history of Heart Burn was diagnosed with Barrett’s oesophagus. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Barrett’s Oesophagus

  • Characterized by Columnar metaplasia
  • In lower part/distal oesophagus- Squamous mucosa is replaced by columnar mucosa
  • MC Columnar epithelium – Intestinal Epithelium (hence, aka Intestinal metaplasia)

Aetiology

questions.text: A 45-year-old female underwent a hysterectomy for a massive fibroid uterus. Post-operatively, the patient developed ileus. First to recover from post-operative ileus is :
questions.solution:
POST-OPERATIVE ILEUS

  • Following most abdominal operations or injuries, the motility of GI tract is transiently impaired.
  • Proposed mechanisms responsible for this dysmotility are surgical stress-induced sympathetic reflexes, inflammatory response mediator release, and anaesthetic / analgesic effects; each of which can inhibit intestinal motility
  • The return of normal motility generally follows a characteristic temporal sequence
    • Return of normal motility: small intestine(within 24 hours) > Gastric (48 hours)>Colonic (3-5 days)
    • Post-operative ileus is most pronounced in colon.
  • Because small bowel motility is returned before colonic and gastric motility, listening for bowel sounds is not a reliable indicator that ileus has fully resolved
  • Functional evidence of coordinated gastrointestinal motility in the form of passing flatus or bowel movement is a more useful indicator

questions.text: A new-born was bought to paediatric ER with complaint of failure to thrive. Infant had history of jaundice at birth and had passed pale grey stool. Hepatobiliary scintigraphy showed increased uptake in liver without any flow into intestine. What will be the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has biliary atresia, a rare disease characterized by fibro-proliferative obliteration of the biliary tree, which progresses toward hepatic fibrosis, cirrhosis, and end-stage liver failure.

Surgical treatment is the first-line therapy, consisting of creation of a hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure).

Infants treated prior to 60 days of life are more likely to achieve successful biliary drainage than older infants.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are true about polymyositis?

Limb-girdle weakness
Ophthalmoplegia
Para-neoplastic syndrome
Spontaneous discharge in EMG
questions.solution:
• Polymyositis presents with symmetrical proximal muscle weakness. Pelvic girdle muscles are more involved than upper body muscles.
  • Ocular muscles are never involved in generalized polymyositis. The actual onset of Poly-myositis is often not easily determined.
  • This is in contrast to dermatomyositis, in which the rash facilitates early recognition.
  • Polymyositis mimics many other myopathies and is a diagnosis of exclusion.

It is a subacute inflammatory myopathy affecting adults, and rarely children, who do NOT have any of the following:

  1. Rash, involvement of the extraocular and facial muscles,
  2. Family history of a neuromuscular disease
  3. History of exposure to myotoxic drugs or toxins
  4. Endocrinopathy, neurogenic disease, muscular dystrophy
  5. Biochemical muscle disorder (deficiency of a muscle enzyme)

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with history of intermittent weakness and muscle fatigue which worsened with activity was diagnosed as a case of Myasthenia Gravis. questions.solution: Thymic abnormalities occur in ~75% of AChR antibody–positive patients. Neoplastic change (thymoma) may produce enlargement of the thymus, which is detected by chest computed tomography (CT). A thymic shadow on CT scan may normally be present through young adulthood, but enlargement of the thymus in a patient age >40 years is highly suspicious of thymoma.

questions.text: A 36 years old male presented to OPD with complains of mild chest pain, difficulty in breathing, low grade fever ,fatigue and swelling over both ankles . O/E - Pulsus paradoxus + , JVP shows +ve Kussmaul sign, increased liver span , positive Puddle sign and absent apex beat. On auscultation - Soft S1, S2, Pericardial knock + , B/L fine crepts +, .CXR shows Egg in a cup appearance and doppler shows Square root wave sign. What is your likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Pericardial knock- early diastolic sound ( earlier than S3 ) indicates decreased ventricular compliance due to an external force heard in patients with constrictive pericarditis
  • S3 is an early diastolic sound due to rapid ventricular filling with a large volume of blood so occur in patients with hyperdynamic circulation example : pregnancy, anemia, A-V shunts and congestive heart failure
  • S4 filling of ventricle against a stiff ventricle so the atria have to give a final kick at end of diastole to completely empty itself

Constrictive pericarditis

  • Pulsusparadoxus
  • Deep x descent
  • Rapid y descent
  • Prominent ‘v’
  • Absent Apex beat
  • S1 S2=soft
  • S3 S4= Never seen
  • Third heart sound=Pericardial Knock
  • Doppler = Square root wave sign
  • CXR = Egg in a cup appearance

questions.text: A 65 year old lady underwent mastectomy for Carcinoma breast. Later she developed frontal headache, pain in temple region and around eye. Her ESR is 55 mm/hour. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
GIANT CELL ARTERITIS

  • Headache, scalp tenderness, visual symptoms, jaw claudication, or throat pain
  • The temporal artery is usually normal on physical examination but may be nodular, enlarged, tender, or pulseless
  • Blindness - Results from occlusive arteritis of the posterior ciliary branch of the ophthalmic artery
  • Ischemic optic neuropathy may produce no funduscopic findings for the first 24–48 hours after the onset of blindness
  • Asymmetry of pulses in the arms, a murmur of aortic regurgitation, or bruits heard near the clavicle resulting from subclavian artery stenoses identify an affected aorta or its major branches
  • Forty percent of patients with giant cell arteritis have nonclassic symptoms at presentation, primarily respiratory tract problems (most frequently dry cough), mononeuritis multiplex (most frequently with painful paralysis of a shoulder), or fever of unknown origin
  • The fever can be as high as 40°C and is frequently associated with rigors and sweats
  • Unexplained head or neck pain in an older patient may signal the presence of giant cell arteritis

Diagnosis

  • An elevated ESR, with a median result of about 65 mm/h, occurs in more than 90% of patients with polymyalgia rheumatica or giant cell arteritis
  • Magnetic resonance angiography or CT angiography establishes the diagnosis by demonstrating long stretches of narrowing of the subclavian and axillary arteries
  • Imaging of the temporal artery with ultrasound, MRI, or CT angiography can sometimes obviate the need for biopsy
  • Temporal artery biopsy -Diagnostic findings of giant cell arteritis may still be present 2 weeks (or even considerably longer) after starting corticosteroids

TREATMENT

  • The urgency of early diagnosis and treatment in giant cell arteritis relates to the prevention of blindness
  • When a patient has symptoms and findings suggestive of temporal arteritis, therapy with prednisone, 60 mg daily orally, is initiated immediately
  • Prednisone should be continued in a dosage of 60 mg/day for 1–2 months before tapering
  • Intravenous pulse methylprednisolone (eg, 1 g/day for 3 days) may help patients with visual loss and may increase chance of remission; however, data supporting this recommendation are preliminary
  • Low-dose aspirin (∼81 mg/day orally) may reduce the risk of visual loss or stroke and should be added to prednisone
  • Tocilizumab, an anti-interleukin-6 receptor monoclonal antibody
  • Phase 2 clinical trials have shown that patients initially treated withtocilizumaband prednisone were able to be tapered off prednisone faster than those who were treated with prednisone alone
  • After 1 year of treatment,tocilizumabachieves corticosteroid-free remission in approximately 50% of patients

questions.text: A patient of CKD has presented with protracted vomiting. ABG shows pH = 7.40, pCO2 = 40 mm Hg, Na=145 mEq/L, Chloride = 100 mEq/L, HCO3 = 24 mEq/L. What is the observation?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
• AG(Anion Gap) = Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-) = 145-124 = 21 meq
  • Normal 8-10meq (Rules out option A)
  • CKD is condition where patient experiences impaired ability to excrete H+
  • Vomiting contributes to metabolic alkalosis
  • Two processes simultaneously occurring, So answer is High anion gap metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis.

Allen test
Add 0.5 ml heparin to the syringe prior to use

Heparin should be flushed inside syringe to prevent clotting. If we add 0.5ml heparin to the syringe, it may lead to factitious results.

questions.text: A haemophiliac child with current bleeding episode is treated with 2 units of FFP. 2 hours after transfusion he has developed breathlessness, hypotension with bilateral crepitations. CXR shows bilateral infiltrates. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare but serious syndrome characterized by sudden acute respiratory distress following transfusion. It is defined as new, acute lung injury (ALI) during or within six hours after blood product administration in the absence of temporally-associated risk factors for ALI.
  • Transfusion of part of one unit of any blood product can causeTRALI.
  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), is a clinical syndrome in which there is acute, noncardiogenic pulmonary edema associated with hypoxia that occurs during or after a transfusion.
  • Intransfusion medicine,transfusion associated circulatory overload(akaTACO) is atransfusion reaction(anadverseeffectofblood transfusion) that can occur due to a rapid transfusion of a large volume ofblood, but can also occur during a single red cell transfusion (about 15% of cases).The fluid volume causeshypervolemia.
  • The primary symptoms of TACO aredyspnea,orthopnea, peripheraledema, and rapid increase ofblood pressure.TACO must be suspected when there is respiratory distress with other signs, including pulmonary edema, unanticipated cardiovascular system changes, and evidence of fluid overload (including improvement afterdiuretic, morphine or nitrate treatment), during or up to 24 hours after transfusion.

questions.text: What is the Neutrophil count for moderate neutropenia?

The risk of bacterial infection is related to both the severity and duration of the neutropenia.

  • Content - radial artery (Pulse can be felt by palpating radial artery against scaphoid bone).

questions.text: Cardiac dominance plays an essential role in cardiac surgery, particularly coronary artery bypass grafting. It is determined by the coronary artery:-

choices.text: Supplying circulation to the SA node
Supplying circulation to the inferior portion of the interventricular septum
Supplying circulation to the interatrial septum
Supplying circulation to the anterior portion of the interventricular septum

questions.solution:
• Cardiac dominance is determined by posterior interventricular artery (PIVA) which supplies posteroinferior part of interventricular septum.
  • Mostly this a branch of Right Coronary Artery so right cardiac dominance (65% of population)
  • If posterior interventricular artery arise from left coronary artery, then it is left cardiac dominance in 10% of population (bad prognosis)
  • Multiple PIVA one from right side one from left side that is codominance in 25% of population.

questions.text: Choroid plexus, made of connective tissue, blood vessels and ependymal cells, produces the CSF.In which of the following components of ventricular system, is choroid plexus present in?
questions.solution:

questions.text: General visceral efferents (GVEs) are fibers under the autonomic nervous system that provide motor innervation via postganglionic varicosities. They do not supply?
questions.solution:

questions.text:
Match the following:



 I. Melanin
a) Black coloured urine


 II. Homogentisic acid
b) Derived from Tyrosine


 III. Hemosiderin
c) Brown atrophy


 IV. Lipofuscin
d) Shows Perl’s reaction
questions.solution:
1. MELANIN

  • Endogenous black pigment
  • Provides hair & skin colour
  • Derived from TYROSINE
  • Protects skin from UV rays
  • Identified by Masson Fontana strain
  • PAS positive unlike Pseudo-melanin

2. Homgenestic Acid

  • Seen in patients suffering from Alkaptonuria
  • Deposits in skin, cartilage and connective tissue of patients k/a Ochronsis
  • Black coloured urine

3. HEMOSIDERIN → Derived from Iron

  • Present at storage sites of iron [Bone marrow, liver, macrophages]
  • Seen in hemochromatosis, chronic Hemolytic anemia, repeated blood transfusions [Thalassemia]
  • Detected by PRUSSIAN BLUE - Purple / violet granules - Reaction Known as PERLS Reaction

LIPOFUSCIN/LIPOCHROME/ wear & tear pigment /pigment of Ageing

  • PERI NUCLEAR BROWN Pigment
  • Lipid derived pigment
  • Associated with brown atrophy
  • Accumulated by LIPID PEROXIDATION
  • Associated with free radical injury

questions.text: A 60-year-old male, chronic smoker, presented with fatigue and chest pain. On examination, there was inset left eyeball with drooping upper left eyelid and reduced left pupil size. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this condition?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma involving the apex of his left lung
A small-cell carcinoma involving the hilum of his left lung
Bronchioloalveolar carcinoma involving the left lower lobe

questions.solution:
• Most tumors of the apex of the lung are adenocarcinomas
  • Pancoast tumors -apical lung tumors in the superior pulmonary sulcus tend to invade the neural structures around the trachea, including the cervical sympathetic plexus.
  • Involvement of sympathetic fibres gives rise to severe pain in the distribution of the ulnar nerve andHorner syndrome.

Features of Horner syndrome are:

A Anhidrosis
M Miosis
P Ptosis
L Loss of ciliospinal reflex

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with a 4cm mass in upper outer quadrant of the breast. Biopsy showed densely packed cells within large lakes of mucin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Colloid (mucinous) carcinomais an invasive variant.

  • Colloid carcinoma has a glistening surface and mucoid consistency on cut section
  • Composed of small clusters of epithelial cells, occasionally forming glands, floating in pools of extracellular mucin.
  • In its pure form, colloid carcinoma has a considerably better prognosis than infiltrating ductal or lobular carcinoma
  • Abundant mucin production is not a feature of the other choices.
  • Diagnosis: Mucinous carcinoma of the breast

questions.text:
